user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_lookup_connection_value_n:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_lookup_connection_value_n (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                               enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                               const char *key,
                               size_t key_size,
                               const char **value_ptr,
                               size_t *value_size_ptr)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos;

  if (NULL == connection)
    return MHD_NO;

  if (NULL == key)
  {
    for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
    {
      if ( (0 != (kind & pos->kind)) &&
           (NULL == pos->header) )
        break;
    }
  }
  else
  {
    for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
    {
      if ( (0 != (kind & pos->kind)) &&
           (key_size == pos->header_size) &&
           ( (key == pos->header) ||
             (MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (key,
                                             pos->header,
                                             key_size) ) ) )
        break;
    }
  }

  if (NULL == pos)
    return MHD_NO;

  if (NULL != value_ptr)
    *value_ptr = pos->value;

  if (NULL != value_size_ptr)
    *value_size_ptr = pos->value_size;

  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_lookup_connection_value_n (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                               enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                               const char *key,
                               size_t key_size,
                               const char **value_ptr,
                               size_t *value_size_ptr)
explanation: I inspected the rest of the function and found no obvious compiler-specific language extensions. There are no occurrences of common compiler extensions such as __attribute__((...)), __declspec(...), __asm, asm(...), typeof, statement-expressions ({: ... }), nested functions, labels-as-values (&label), or other GCC/Clang/MSVC specific keywords. The remaining constructs are standard C: enums, pointers, size_t, for-loops, pointer comparisons, function calls, and simple bitwise operations. Reserved identifier usage (identifiers beginning with an underscore) is a concern per the C standard but is not itself a compiler language extension and therefore was not flagged here. The only candidate that could map to a compiler-specific linkage/visibility extension is the _MHD_EXTERN token at the function start (it is likely a macro that may expand to a compiler-specific storage-class or attribute); that macro usage is reported for investigation. No other fragments in the provided code contain explicit compiler extensions as documented by common compilers.
